Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5W2X-YPS1-JCBW-N28T-00000-00A punt on Uber is a bold gamble to make;THE CITY VIEW2019-05-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:15:12ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2A punt on Uber is a bold gamble to makeTHE CITY VIEW

EVERY time you jump into an Uber, your ride is essentially subsidised by venture capitalists who prop up the lossmaking outfit in the hope of riches down the road. Later today in New York, many more hopefuls will get the chance to back the immensely-popular-yet-controversial tech firm when it finally comes to market.

Similarly to its smaller rival Lyft, Uber's business model and valuation leans on two expectations: firstly, that new technologies such as driverless cars will slash costs and revolutionise urban transport; secondly, that the companies in question will have sufficiently dominant market positions to take advantage of these futuristic developments. This is not a mere pipe-dream. Great progress has already been made in the field of automated, clean vehicles, and Uber's expansion into cities across the globe - not to mention its attainment of a key place in the modern lexicon - has been phenomenal. Its potential is enormously exciting, hence rumours of valuations in excess of $100bn (£77bn) doing the rounds of late.

However the warning signs are numerous, not least as Uber's final valuation has come in at just $82.4bn. The future of transport, especially on our roads, is fiercely competitive and prone to a range of uncertainties surrounding infrastructure, regulation, technological capabilities and consumer preferences. Meanwhile, electric and driverless car technology continues to attract a large number of companies from various sectors, such as Dyson, which revealed patents for a new electric car this week. Who is to say which firms will prove most successful in this intriguing but uncertain space? Earlier this week, Warren Buffett was in sage-worthy form when commenting on hyped flotations. "The idea of saying the best place in the world I could put my money is something where all the selling incentives are there, commissions are higher, the animal spirits are rising, that it's going to be better than 1,000 other things I could buy where there is no similar enthusiasm… just doesn't make any sense," Buffett told CNBC. Amazon proved that the loss-making model of rapid expansion can work.

Facebook proved that big tech floats can deliver exceptional returns. But there are a string of examples, including Lyft, in which such endeavours splutter to a halt. A punt on Uber represents a bold gamble, not just on the company's management, but on how the future of transport will look.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VY3-KV01-DXY4-X2XC-00000-00A Pure Internet or Free Speech?2019-04-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:15:12ZLexisNexisSection BColumn 0Business/Financial DeskPg. 3BITSA Pure Internet or Free Speech?By JAMIE CONDLIFFE

Each week, we review the week's news, offering analysis about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.

Hi, I'm Jamie Condliffe. Greetings from London. Here's a look at the week's tech news:

In the quest to clean up the web, the gray area between good and bad will be hard to handle.

As the Notre-Dame cathedral in Paris burned last Monday, a YouTube effort to fight misinformation failed. The platform's automated fact-checking feature -- a box that shows facts to help viewers contextualize footage -- incorrectly displayed information about the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks alongside live streams of the fire.

''These panels are triggered algorithmically, and our systems sometimes make the wrong call,'' YouTube said in a statement. The company said it had no further details about what went wrong.

The failure raises a question: If a platform can't provide facts reliably, how can we trust it to take down bad content correctly?

Facebook, YouTube and other Big Tech companies say malign content will have to be policed automatically, because it's too big a job for humans. But algorithms will struggle against our subjectivity.

This is a hard problem. In a profile by my colleague Daisuke Wakabayashi, YouTube's chief executive, Susan Wojcicki, said borderline content -- material that is potentially harmful but does not break rules -- was particularly hard to police.

Rasmus Nielsen, a professor of political communication at Oxford University who studies misinformation, said, ''The problem will never be solved, if solving it means getting rid of all the bad stuff, because we can't agree on what the bad stuff is.''

Accept that, and a hard question follows. ''Knowing that things won't be perfect, what do we feel is most desirable?'' Mr. Nielsen asked. ''A system that errs on the side of caution, or one that errs on the side of being permissive?''

Decisions on that appear set to be shaped by regulation, such as draft legislation approved by the European Union on Wednesday that would require platforms to take down terrorist content within one hour of notification from the authorities, or this month's proposals from Britain to fine tech companies if they don't remove ''harmful'' content quickly.

This quickly descends into the thorny issue of potentially infringing rights of free speech to ensure that platforms remain clean. Lawmakers will have to wrestle with what kinds of algorithms they want deployed to enforce their regulation, and there is no easy solution.

Apple's big 5G backdown

For years, Apple and Qualcomm were locked in bitter patent battles across three continents. The iPhone maker sought $27 billion in damages; its former chip supplier wanted $15 billion.

My colleagues Don Clark and Daisuke Wakabayashi reported on Wednesday that the companies had agreed to dismiss their litigation. The settlement includes a multiyear agreement for Qualcomm to supply chips to Apple, and an undisclosed one-time payment to Qualcomm from Apple.

Why the change? Playing a big role were two small characters: 5G.

Both companies care deeply about it. As The Wall Street Journal noted, Qualcomm ''trained its focus on the future promises of 5G'' for more than two years, concentrating its efforts on developing standards and new chips that enable smartphones to access the networks. The new 5G technology will provide far faster data speeds, and is expected to be widely adopted in the coming years.

Apple has worried about its source for those chips. While it was locked in battle with Qualcomm, the chip maker's components -- which are already fit for inclusion in phones -- were not an option. That left some unpalatable options:

â–  Go with Intel, its 4G supplier. But rumors of delays at Intel suggested that could have pushed back the release of a 5G iPhone by a year.

â–  Team up with Huawei, which said Tuesday that it was ''open'' to selling 5G chips to Apple. But that could look bad for the iPhone maker, given Washington's concerns about national security risks posed by Huawei.

â–  Build its own. But Apple's chip design team is relatively new, so that could have taken a long time.

Against that backdrop, the desire for $27 billion in damages faltered.

Apple will probably still want to work with another modem supplier, but for now the situation appears to be mutually beneficial for the two companies.

Less so for Intel, perhaps: Just hours after the settlement was announced, the company said it would no longer work on 5G smartphone chips, citing ''no clear path to profitability.''

The gamer with 45,000 years of experience

Last weekend, OpenAI, an artificial intelligence research organization, gave one of its algorithms a tough challenge: It had to play the strategy video game Dota 2 against a team of the world's most proficient human players.

Dota 2 is difficult. Two teams of five players battle each other, but have incomplete information (they can't see the whole game arena), lots of complexity (each player can make dozens of actions across a large playing area) and must think in advance (games last around 45 minutes).

OpenAI's algorithm uses five so-called artificial neural networks, each controlling a player, that learn by playing games against themselves. The ones that played last weekend boasted the equivalent of 45,000 years of total game play experience.

''It's almost an evolutionary scale,'' Greg Brockman, the chief technology officer of OpenAI, said. ''It's perfectly honed for its environment.''

How did the algorithms do? They won, taking the first two games in a best-of-three competition.

''It's a significant milestone,'' Shimon Whiteson, a professor of computer science at Oxford University, said. And it ''shows that we still haven't reached the limits of what we can achieve when using existing algorithms,'' he added.

OpenAI faces another test this weekend, when it takes on teams worldwide over the internet. Mr. Brockman says there is a ''50-50 shot that we'll win every game.''

But the news highlights a problem facing A.I.: its astonishing demand for computer power to master a single task. The 45,000 years of experience took 10 months to acquire on thousands of powerful computer processors, and the algorithms would need other training to master a new skill. Overcoming that is one of the biggest challenges in A.I.

And some stories you shouldn't miss

â–  China is using A.I. to profile a minority group. Hundreds of thousands of face scans and new algorithms have enabled the government to track members of a largely Muslim group.

â–  Google's huge data cache is being used as a dragnet. Its user tracking is being employed by investigators to find suspects and witnesses near crimes, but it could snare the innocent.

â–  Insurance doesn't necessarily cover cyberattacks. Big companies thought they were covered for losses resulting from the 2017 NotPetya attack. They were wrong.

â–  Samsung's $2,000 foldable-screen smartphone is already breaking. Some gadget reviewers found that its screen failed after several days of use.

â–  Silicon Valley is giving second chances to #MeToo culprits. Executives fired for misconduct are finding it relatively easy to get new jobs, reports BuzzFeed News.

â–  Apple's gaming service has a big budget. The FT reports that it's spending $500 million on titles for its launch.

â–  Want to relive Facebook's troubled 15 months? Wired's 12,000-word essay will help.

â–  Google quietly disbanded another ethics board. A panel overseeing the ethics of its health care A.I. split up over tensions about information access and independence.

â–  Alibaba's co-founder celebrated a 72-hour workweek. Jack Ma said that working from 9 a.m. until 9 p.m., six days a week, was a ''huge blessing.''

This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

PHOTO: YouTube failed to excise misinformation as the Notre-Dame cathedral burned last week, as 9/11 details cropped up next to the fire videos. (PHOTOGRAPH BY STEPHANE DE SAKUTIN/AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE -- GETTY IMAGES)

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:4243-4XD0-00BT-M0JB-00000-00AP Weekly News Calendar Saturday, Jan. 13:2001-01-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:15:12ZLexisNexisInternational newsAP Weekly News Calendar Saturday, Jan. 13:

Hong Kong Falun Gong practitioners, gathering for international conference of sect banned in mainland China, plan to march toward Chinese government liaison office.

Kobe, Japan Finance ministers of Asia-Europe Meeting nations discuss expansion of ASEM Trust Fund. Through Jan. 14.

Cairo, Egypt Hearing in spy trial of Shereef Fawzi Mohammed el-Falali, engineer accused of spying for Israel.

Vilnius, Lithuania Lithuania marks 10th anniversary of TV tower killings during Soviet crackdown.

Oporto, Portugal Oporto begins yearlong stint as European Cultural Capital, shared with Rotterdam, Netherlands.

Amman, Jordan Chinese vice president visits as part of five-nation tour.

Athens, Greece Japanese Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori visits after wrapping up African tour. Meeting Premier Costas Simitis and touring archaeological sights. Through Jan. 14.

Sunday, Jan. 14:

Hong Kong Falun Gong followers from around world hold conference inside Hong Kong's city hall.

Lisbon, Portugal Presidential election.

Praia, Cape Verde General election in Cape Verde, island nation off West Africa.

Amman, Jordan Australian immigration minister arrives as part of closer cooperation on curbing illegal Iraqi immigration to Australia.

Milan, Italy Men's Fashion Week. Through Jan. 18.

Monday, Jan. 15:

Damanhour, Egypt Jewish pilgrims expected to visit tomb of revered Rabbi Abu Hatzeira. Tension over annual visit expected to be higher because of Egyptian anger over Israeli-Palestinian violence.

Srinagar, India Village council elections in Jammu-Kashmir, first in 32 years. Starts in areas most vulnerable to disruption by Islamic separatists; ends two months later in Srinagar, state's summer capital.

New Delhi, India Human Resources Minister Murli Manohar appears before Liberhan Commission probing demolition of Babri mosque.

Calcutta, India Jhumpa Lahiri, Pulitzer Prize-winning Indian American author, to wed Alberto Vourvoulias of Time magazine in gala Hindu ceremony.

Tuesday, Jan. 16:

Frankfurt, Germany Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer testifies as character witness in murder trial of former friend from days as radical in 1970s.

Kuwait Constitutional Court to rule whether Kuwaiti women should have right to vote and run for office.

Cairo, Egypt Trial resumes for prominent government critic Saad Eddin Ibrahim and 27 others charged with illegally accepting foreign funds, conspiring to bribe and making false statements about Egypt.

Athens, Greece Yugoslav President Vojslav Kustonica scheduled to visit.

Wednesday, Jan. 17:

New Delhi, India British physicist Stephen Hawking gives Albert Einstein Lecture on ''Predicting the Future: From Astrology to Black Holes.''

Thursday, Jan. 18:

George Town, Cayman Islands Britain's minister for overseas territories visits Caribbean to discuss controversial issues, including banking secrecy and lack of tolerance for homosexuality. Through Jan. 20.

Stockholm, Sweden Arraignment for four of five suspects in theft of Rembrandt and Renoir paintings from National Museum.

Friday, Jan. 19:

Allahabad, India Policy-making body of Vishwa Hindu Parishad, Hindu nationalist group that influences India's governing party, meets to decide date for starting temple at site of Muslim mosque demolished in 1992. Razing touched off bloody riots. Through Jan. 21.

New Delhi, India Three Hinduja brothers, owners of British-based global business empire, to appear in court to challenge allegations of bribery and receiving kickbacks in arms purchase case.

Pszczyna, Poland Presidents of Poland, Hungary, Slovakia and Czech Republic hold annual meeting on regional cooperation.

Saturday, Jan. 20:

Philipsburg, St. Maarten Dutch Queen Beatrix arrives for state visit to her Caribbean territories of St. Maarten, St. Eustatius and Saba. Through Jan. 24.

Tehran, Iran Tehran-Palestine Solidarity Week, featuring poetry readings, movie screenings and musical performances on plight of Palestinians. Through Jan 26.

Budapest, Hungary Funeral for Hungarian pop idol Jimmy Zambo, who killed himself Jan. 2.

Sunday, Jan. 21:

Allahabad, India Hindu nationalists to announce day for beginning construction of temple on site of Muslim mosque destroyed in 1992. Demolition caused riots in which more than 2,000 people died.

Cairo, Egypt Egyptian Cabinet presents policy proposals to new parliament.

Norrkoeping, Sweden European Union ministers for gender equality and social security meet. Through Jan. 23.

WORLD AT 0700

MIDEAST PEACE: Israeli-Palestinian peace talks resume, reviving hopes of an accord

JERUSALEM Top Palestinian and Israeli negotiators take newly resumed peace talks into the early hours Friday, making a last-ditch push for accord in the eight days left in U.S. President Bill Clinton's term. ISRAEL-PALESTINIANS. Lead has moved. By Ellen Knickmeyer. AP Photos.

NO GUN RI: US Army says soldiers killed South Korean civilians; Clinton expresses regret

WASHINGTON The U.S. Army acknowledges that American soldiers shot to death an ''unknown number'' of South Korean refugees early in the Korean War, but says there is no evidence they were ordered to do so. ''I deeply regret that Korean civilians lost their lives at No Gun Ri,'' President Bill Clinton says, stopping short of an apology. US-NO GUN RI. Lead has moved. By Robert Burns. AP Photos SEO102, WX119, 121-122, 124-125.

WITH:

ANALYSIS-NO GUN RI-RESPONSIBILITY. Reports by U.S. and South Korean investigators end decades of official silence on the refugee killings at No Gun Ri, but left a core question hanging: Who bears responsibility? Has moved.

NO GUN RI-SURVIVORS. Survivors of the killing of refugees by American soldiers at No Gun Ri angrily denounced as a whitewash the U.S. Army's report that there was no evidence that the soldiers were ordered to kill. Has moved.

EUROPE:

CZECH-TELEVISION: Director of Czech Television resigns, but standoff continues

PRAGUE, Czech Republic Despite the resignation of Jiri Hodac, the director of Czech Television, there is no end in sight to a three-week standoff between the channel's managers and rebellious staff backed by a vociferous public. CZECH-TELEVISION. Has moved. By Karel Janicek. AP Photos CTK107, FRA121.

WALLENBERG REPORT: Official report on Raoul Wallenberg is not likely to end speculation

STOCKHOLM, Sweden Just one thing is clear about the official report being presented Friday by the Russian-Swedish committee investigating the fate of Swedish diplomat Raoul Wallenberg it's not the end of the story. SWEDEN-WALLENBERG. Has moved. By Kim Gamel.

WAR CRIMES: Bosnian Serb pleads innocent at war crimes tribunal.

THE HAGUE, Netherlands Biljana Plavsic, the most senior Bosnian Serb to face a U.N. war crimes tribunal, pleads innocent to genocide and other crimes against humanity amid speculation that she might be willing to testify against her former cohorts. WAR CRIMES-BOSNIA. Has moved. By Jerome Socolovsky. AP Photos HAG101-104.

ASIA:

HONG KONG-POLITICS: Reports: Hong Kong's top civil servant quitting

HONG KONG The territory's No. 2 official is quitting in a move that would severe the highest-level continuity between Hong Kong's colonial British past and present Chinese sovereignty, local media reports Friday. HONG KONG-POLITICS. Lead has moved. By Margaret Wong. AP Photos HK101-103.

LIBEL TRIAL: Proceedings begin in Taiwanese vice president's libel trial

TAIPEI, Taiwan Proceedings begin in the bizarre trial involving Vice President Annette Lu and a weekly news magazine. Lu accuses the magazine of libeling her in an article that said she called a reporter and hinted that President Chen Shui-bian was having an affair with an aide. TAIWAN-POLITICS. Expected by 0800 GMT. By Annie Huang.

ESTRADA IMPEACHMENT: Court calls new witnesses on stock scandal

MANILA, Philippines Prosecutors in President Joseph Estrada's impeachment trial call new witnesses to support their allegations that the Philippine leader made a fortune from shares at the heart of the country's biggest-ever stock scandal. PHILIPPINES-ESTRADA. Expected by 0900 GMT. By Oliver Teves.

TIANANMEN PAPERS: Scholars defend authenticity of leaked Tiananmen documents

NEW YORK Several U.S.-based China experts defend the authenticity of newly published documents depicting Chinese leaders squabbling over how to suppress the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests, but questioned the suggestion that their release could spur democratic reforms. US-TIANANMEN PAPERS. Has moved. By Priscilla Cheung.

JAPAN-POETRY: Imperial family holds unusual poetry reading at the palace

TOKYO The hopes of parenthood. The frailties of old age. A mother's death. In classic austerity and choreographed precision, the imperial family holds an annual poetry reading at the palace, reflecting centuries of tradition and the troubles of modern Japan. JAPAN-IMPERIAL POETRY. Has moved. By Joseph Coleman.

CHINA-US: U.S., Chinese veterans of Korean Warn conclude confidence-building meetings

BEIJING U.S. and Chinese veterans of the Korean War conclude exchanges described as confidence building exercises leading up to larger discussions on the issue of soldiers still missing from the conflict half a century ago. CHINA-US-VETERAN. Expected by 1100 GMT. By Christopher Bodeen.

AMERICAS:

PARADISE LOST: Peace-seeking European commune flees rebel violence in Colombia

PACHO, Colombia They came looking for paradise in the Andes, and instead found disillusionment and death. For Jenny James and the little band of starry-eyed followers who arrived in Colombia in 1989 from a commune in Ireland, the verdant mountains of the southern part of the country seemed perfect. FEA-COLOMBIA-PARADISE LOST. Has moved. By Margarita Martinez. AP Photo NY199.

CANADA: Lucien Bouchard resigns as Quebec premier

QUEBEC Lucien Bouchard had insisted he would call another referendum on sovereignty for Quebec when the ''winning conditions'' existed. Convinced he was unable to create those conditions, Bouchard resigns as premier of the Francophone province and leader of the separatist Parti Quebecois. CANADA-QUEBEC LEADER. Recap has moved. By Phil Couvrette. AP Photos QBC101, 103, 105-108, 110; MTL103, CPT114.

CAMPAIGN FINANCE: Indonesian to pay record dlrs 8.6 million fine for Clinton contributions

WASHINGTON Indonesian billionaire James Riady has agreed to pay a record dlrs 8.6 million criminal fine and plead guilty to using corporate funds from his foreign Lippo Group to reimburse contributors to Bill Clinton's 1992 campaign for the presidency, the Justice Department announces. Foreign campaign contributions are illegal under U.S. law. US-RIADY. Lead has moved. By Michael J. Sniffen.

US-EXECUTION: First black woman executed in U.S. since 1954

McALESTER, Oklahoma A woman convicted of killing a childhood friend and later murdering a lesbian lover is executed, becoming the first black woman executed in the United States since 1954. US-EXECUTION-BLACK WOMAN. Lead has moved. By Rochelle Hines. AP Photos OKJL104-107, JPC102-106.

AFRICA:

GHANA'S VICTORY: A onetime dictator loses in Ghana, but democratic process wins

ACCRA, Ghana Last Sunday's presidential in Ghana was a rare victory for democracy in West Africa, where transfers of power more often take place through coups or civil wars than through the ballot box. GHANA'S VICTORY. Has moved. By Kwasi Kpodo.

UN-SOMALIA: US signaling support for new U.N. involvement in Somalia

UNITED NATIONS Six years after the United Nations pulled out of Somalia in disgrace, the Security Council on Thursday endorsed tentative U.N. plans to return to the country with a small mission to help the fragile new government consolidate peace and rebuild. UN-SOMALIA. Sent. By Nicole Winfield.

BUSINESS AND FINANCE:

US-AOL-TIME WARNER: AOL-Time Warner deal wins FCC approval

WASHINGTON The dlrs 106 billion merger of America Online and Time Warner clears its final government hurdle, paving the way for the creation of the nation's largest media empire. US-AOL-TIME WARNER. Lead has moved. By Kalpana Srinivasan. AP Photos WX126-127.

JAPAN-MARKETS: Dollar rises against yen, Tokyo stocks rise

TOKYO The U.S. dollar rises to a new 18-month high against the yen Friday amid investor worries that Japan's economic recovery may be stalling. Tokyo stocks are higher.

__

NO GUN RI: US Army says soldiers killed South Korean civilians; Clinton expresses regret

WASHINGTON The U.S. Army acknowledges that American soldiers shot to death an ''unknown number'' of South Korean refugees early in the Korean War, but says there is no evidence they were ordered to do so. ''I deeply regret that Korean civilians lost their lives at No Gun Ri,'' President Bill Clinton says, stopping short of an apology. US-NO GUN RI. Lead has moved. By Robert Burns. AP Photos SEO102, WX119, 121-122, 124-125.

WITH:

ANALYSIS-NO GUN RI-RESPONSIBILITY. Reports by U.S. and South Korean investigators end decades of official silence on the refugee killings at No Gun Ri, but left a core question hanging: Who bears responsibility? Has moved.

NO GUN RI-SURVIVORS. Survivors of refugees killed by American soldiers at No Gun Ri angrily denounce a report by the U.S. Army that says there was no evidence the soldiers were ordered to shoot. They said it was a whitewash and demanded another investigation. Developing.

US-NO GUN RI-ALLIES: In acknowledging that American soldiers killed South Korean refugees at No Gun Ri, the Clinton administration struck a balance between soothing the anger of a valued ally and preserving the honor of U.S. troops who fought in the Korean War. Has moved.

US-NO GUN RI-SUMMARY. Has moved.

PRISTINA, Yugoslavia In an emotional farewell speech Friday, the top U.N. administrator in Kosovo begs the leaders of the province's various ethnic groups to bring an end to violence. ''My final message to you is simple: stop the killings my dear friends, stop the violence,'' Bernard Kouchner said. KOSOVO-KOUCHNER. Has moved. By Fisnik Abrashi. AP Photos.

BRITAIN-BATTERED ANNA: Judge jails aunt and boyfriend for life for killing girl they abused

LONDON Eight-year-old Anna Climbie was tied in a plastic garbage bag and forced to sleep in a bath; she was beaten with a bicycle chain and fed on scraps. On Friday, a judge jailed Anna's great-aunt Marie Therese Kouao, 44, and her 28-year-old boyfriend for life for murdering the youngster in a case that has horrified Britain. BRITAIN-BATTERED ANNA. Has moved. AP Photos LON104-106.

WALLENBERG REPORT: Official report on Raoul Wallenberg is not likely to end speculation

STOCKHOLM, Sweden Swedish investigators probing what happened to former Swedish diplomat and Holocaust hero Raoul Wallenberg conclude that the government should have pressed harder for answers decades ago, and now the truth may never be known. SWEDEN-WALLENBERG. Lead has moved. By Kim Gamel. AP Photo NY108, STO101.

RAISING THE KURSK: Efforts to raise sunken submarine to begin in April.

BRUSSELS, Belgium Efforts to lift the sunken Russian nuclear submarine Kursk are to begin in April and will cost around dlrs 70 million, says the Kursk Foundation, the international group set up to organize and fund the operation. RAISING THE KURSK. Has moved. By Constant Brand.

RUSSIA-OLD NEW YEAR: In with the old for peculiar Russian holiday.

MOSCOW As the holiday season winds down in most of the world, Russians have one more day of revelry and a few bottles of vodka still up their sleeves this weekend in a celebration marking Old New Year's Eve. The paradoxical-sounding holiday commemorates the new year according to an old calendar used by the Orthodox Church. RUSSIA-OLD NEW YEAR'S. Expected by 1900 GMT. AP Photo MOSB110.

MIDEAST:

IRAQ-AMERICANS: American activists bound for Baghdad with supplies.

BAGHDAD, Iraq Challenging a decade-old ban on flights to Iraq and defying U.S. export regulations, a group of American activists fly to Baghdad with dlrs 15,000 worth of medical and school supplies. Flight is the latest attempt to chip away at a U.N. sanctions regime that many now see as unjust. IRAQ-DEFIANT AMERICANS. Expected by 2200 GMT. By Greg Myre.

ISRAEL-POLITICS: Polls show Likud leader maintains double-digit lead over Barak

JERUSALEM Three weeks before Israelis elect a prime minister, right-wing opposition leader Ariel Sharon is holding on to a double-digit lead over Prime Minister Ehud Barak and support for a U.S.-proposed peace deal with the Palestinians is weakening, according to polls published Friday. ISRAEL-POLITICS. Has moved.

YEMEN-SHIP ATTACK: Report: Yemen seeks U.S. details on Cole's voyage before deadly blast

ADEN, Yemen Yemen asks the United States for details about the USS Cole's voyage before a bomb blast nearly sank the destroyer in Aden harbor, particularly relating to a comical peddler said to have been allowed aboard at the Suez Canal, according to a Yemeni military newspaper. YEMEN-SHIP ATTACK. Has moved. By Susan Sevareid.

AFRICA:

ZANZIBAR POLITICS: President rejects call for new elections; embassies threatened.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania Zanzibar President Amani Abeid Karume on Friday rejects an opposition ultimatum for fresh elections in the Indian Ocean archipelago, and leaflets appear threatening Western diplomatic missions for pressing the political opposition to recognize his government. TANZANIA-ZANZIBAR POLITICS. Moved. By Rodrique Ngowi.

AMERICAS:

SCI-GAUR CLONE: Cloned ox, from rare species, dies of disease shortly after birth

DES MOINES, Iowa A rare ox called a gaur, cloned and gestated in the womb of a cow in a scientific first, was born this week but died two days later of an ordinary disease, scientists announce Friday. SCI-GAUR CLONE. Has moved.

MEXICO-POLITICS: Mexico's former ruling party struggles to become young again

MEXICO CITY The party that ruled Mexico for 71 years is reaching into its past to survive for the future. With the party losing governorships, and with court decisions paring away at its once ruthlessly efficient electoral machine, it risks becoming a dinosaur unless it can attract new blood. MEXICO-PRI. Expected by 1700 GMT. By Mark Stevenson. Photo planned.

US-MICROSOFT: U.S. denies judge who ordered Microsoft breakup was biased

WASHINGTON The Justice Department told a federal appeals court Friday that the judge who ordered the breakup of Microsoft was not biased as the giant computer software company has alleged. US-MICROSOFT. Has moved. By Michael J. Sniffen.

ASIA:

HONG KONG-POLITICS: Last top Hong Kong official appointed by Britain calls it quits

HONG KONG In a poignant departure raising new questions about Hong Kong's freedoms and future, Anson Chan, the top official appointed by Britain's last colonial governor, calls it quits Friday but insisted her decision was personal and not political. Lead has moved. By Dirk Beveridge. Associated Press Writer. AP Photos HK101-107.

AFGHANISTAN-TALIBAN: Taliban tells new U.S. administration to improve ties

ISLAMABAD, Pakistan Afghanistan's Taliban militia, targeted by the United States for shielding suspected terrorist Osama bin Laden, on Friday urges President-elect George W. Bush to move toward improving ties. AFGHANISTAN-TALIBAN. Has moved. By Kathy Gannon. AP Photo ISL101.

BUSINESS AND FINANCE:

US-ECONOMY: Clinton's final economic report rejects recession fears

WASHINGTON President Bill Clinton sends his last economic report to Congress on Friday, saying that it depicted eight years of ''prosperity and progress.'' He cautions against excessive tax cuts and spending increases which he says could jeopardize that prosperity. US-CLINTON-ECONOMY. Lead has moved. By Martin Crutsinger.

WINE WHINE: New futures market causes indigestion in Bordeaux

PARIS For centuries, when the French spoke of wine derivatives, they were referring to grapes: cabernet sauvignon, pinot noir, merlot. Now, officials at a new financial market are hoping that people with a taste for wine will also be keen to invest in it a proposal that has roiled the nation's most venerable winemakers and merchants and stirred a debate on the future of fine Bordeaux. France-Wine Futures. By Jocelyn Gecker. AP Photo NY135.

EU-AIR MERGER: EU approves merger between United Airlines and US Airways

BRUSSELS, Belgium The European Union approves United Airlines' dlrs 4.3 billion bid to acquire US Airways, saying Friday that its concerns that the deal would reduce competition between Europe and the United States were addressed by United's commitment to sell some airport landing and takeoff rights in Germany. EU-UNITED-US AIRWAYS. Has moved.

__

LOOKING AHEAD: Portugal holds a presidential election Sunday. In Kuwait on Tuesday, the Constitutional Court is scheduled to rule whether Kuwaiti women should have right to vote and run for office.

FEATURES MOVED:

ARTS-YEMEN-SAN'A STYLE. By Donna Bryson. AP Photos NY335-337

ARTS-US-JOHNNY CASH. By Jim Patterson. AP Photo NY346

ARTS-US-REBECCA PIDGEON. By David Germain. AP Photo NY343

ARTS-US-RYAN PHILLIPPE. AP Photo NY352

ARTS-US-PIPE ORGAN FIRM. AP Photo NY358

ARTS-US-SIDNEY LUMET. AP Photo NY359

ARTS-US-CECE WINANS. AP Photo NY347

ARTS-US-JULIA STILES. AP Photos NY344-345

ARTS-US-BUILDING IMAGES. AP Photos NY348-349

ARTS-US-ALIEN MESSAGES. AP Photo NY307

ARTS-US-UNLIKELY BROTHERS. AP Photos NY308-310

ARTS-US-REALITY DUO. AP Photo NY338

ARTS-US-STONE-CUTTING SCHOOL. AP Photos NY367-369

ARTS-US-MATTHEW SHEPARD. AP Photos NY376-377

ARTS-CELEBRITY BIRTHDAYS.

ARTS-FILM REVIEWS.

Contact your local AP bureau or the AP International Desk in New York, telephone: (1) 212-621-1650, fax: (1) 212-621-5449, e-mail: worldnews@ap.org.

Saturday, Jan. 13:

Hong Kong Falun Gong practitioners, gathering for international conference of sect banned in mainland China, plan to march toward Chinese government liaison office.

Kobe, Japan Finance ministers of Asia-Europe Meeting nations discuss expansion of ASEM Trust Fund. Through Jan. 14.

Cairo, Egypt Hearing in spy trial of Shereef Fawzi Mohammed el-Falali, engineer accused of spying for Israel.

Vilnius, Lithuania Lithuania marks 10th anniversary of TV tower killings during Soviet crackdown.

Oporto, Portugal Oporto begins yearlong stint as European Cultural Capital, shared with Rotterdam, Netherlands.

Amman, Jordan Chinese vice president visits as part of five-nation tour.

Athens, Greece Japanese Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori visits after wrapping up African tour. Meeting Premier Costas Simitis and touring archaeological sights. Through Jan. 14.

Sunday, Jan. 14:

Hong Kong Falun Gong followers from around world hold conference inside Hong Kong's city hall.

Lisbon, Portugal Presidential election.

Praia, Cape Verde General election in Cape Verde, island nation off West Africa.

Amman, Jordan Australian immigration minister arrives as part of closer cooperation on curbing illegal Iraqi immigration to Australia.

Milan, Italy Men's Fashion Week. Through Jan. 18.

Morrison, Tenneessee Bridgestone/Firestone scheduled to shut down its bus and truck tire manufacturing plant here for two weeks, idling 900 workers.

Monday, Jan. 15:

Damanhour, Egypt Jewish pilgrims expected to visit tomb of revered Rabbi Abu Hatzeira. Tension over annual visit expected to be higher because of Egyptian anger over Israeli-Palestinian violence.

Srinagar, India Village council elections in Jammu-Kashmir, first in 32 years. Starts in areas most vulnerable to disruption by Islamic separatists; ends two months later in Srinagar, state's summer capital.

New Delhi, India Human Resources Minister Murli Manohar appears before Liberhan Commission probing demolition of Babri mosque.

Calcutta, India Jhumpa Lahiri, Pulitzer Prize-winning Indian American author, to wed Alberto Vourvoulias of Time magazine in gala Hindu ceremony.

United States Martin Luther King Jr. holiday.

Tuesday, Jan. 16:

Frankfurt, Germany Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer testifies as character witness in murder trial of former friend from days as radical in 1970s.

Kuwait Constitutional Court to rule whether Kuwaiti women should have right to vote and run for office.

Cairo, Egypt Trial resumes for prominent government critic Saad Eddin Ibrahim and 27 others charged with illegally accepting foreign funds, conspiring to bribe and making false statements about Egypt.

Athens, Greece Yugoslav President Vojslav Kustonica scheduled to visit.

Baghdad, Iraq Demonstrations commemorating start of 1991 Gulf War.

Camp Zeist, Netherlands Trial of two Libyans accused of blowing up Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, resumes after three-day recess.

Washington Senate Judiciary Committee hearing on the nomination of John Ashcroft to be attorney general.

Wednesday, Jan. 17:

New Delhi, India British physicist Stephen Hawking gives Albert Einstein Lecture on ''Predicting the Future: From Astrology to Black Holes.''

Baghdad, Iraq President Saddam Hussein addresses his nation in speech marking 1991 Gulf War anniversary.

Vienna, Austria OPEC ministers hold a special meeting to discuss production cuts to shore up world oil prices.

Washington Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing on the nomination of Colin Powell to be Secretary of State.

Thursday, Jan. 18:

George Town, Cayman Islands Britain's minister for overseas territories visits Caribbean to discuss controversial issues, including banking secrecy and lack of tolerance for homosexuality. Through Jan. 20.

Stockholm, Sweden Arraignment for four of five suspects in theft of Rembrandt and Renoir paintings from National Museum.

Washington Presidential inaugural opening celebration ceremony.

Los Angeles Sundance film festival. Through Jan. 28.

Friday, Jan. 19:

Allahabad, India Policy-making body of Vishwa Hindu Parishad, Hindu nationalist group that influences India's governing party, meets to decide date for starting temple at site of Muslim mosque demolished in 1992. Razing touched off bloody riots. Through Jan. 21.

New Delhi, India Three Hinduja brothers, owners of British-based global business empire, to appear in court to challenge allegations of bribery and receiving kickbacks in arms purchase case.

Pszczyna, Poland Presidents of Poland, Hungary, Slovakia and Czech Republic hold annual meeting on regional cooperation.

Saturday, Jan. 20:

Philipsburg, St. Maarten Dutch Queen Beatrix arrives for state visit to her Caribbean territories of St. Maarten, St. Eustatius and Saba. Through Jan. 24.

Tehran, Iran Tehran-Palestine Solidarity Week, featuring poetry readings, movie screenings and musical performances on plight of Palestinians. Through Jan 26.

Budapest, Hungary Funeral for Hungarian pop idol Jimmy Zambo, who killed himself Jan. 2.

Washington Presidential Inauguration.

Sunday, Jan. 21:

Allahabad, India Hindu nationalists to announce day for beginning construction of temple on site of Muslim mosque destroyed in 1992. Demolition caused riots in which more than 2,000 people died.

Cairo, Egypt Egyptian Cabinet presents policy proposals to new parliament.

Norrkoeping, Sweden European Union ministers for gender equality and social security meet. Through Jan. 23.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XNY-8991-DYK1-H3KT-00000-00À quand une souveraineté numérique individuelle?;Denys Malengreau Expert belge de l’économie numériqueReputation 3652019-12-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:15:12ZLexisNexisPg. 12À quand une souveraineté numérique individuelle?Denys Malengreau Expert belge de l’économie numériqueReputation 365

La souveraineté, c’est l’autorité, le pouvoir sur ou la maîtrise de… Quand on parle de protection des données, à l’instar du règlement européen en la matière, on risque une double omission celle du processus de collecte sous-jacent et de son corollaire, la souveraineté numérique individuelle. Comprenez: la capacité pour le citoyen d’être pleinement souverain de son identité numérique et des données qui y sont associées. Il faut différencier la vie privée des données de la sécurisation ou protection de celles-ci.

Il importe de comprendre cette distinction pour centrer le débat sur l’essentiel. La vie privée, c’est l’état dans lequel une personne n’est ni dérangée ni observée. Transposée à l’espace numérique, elle suggère une absence de collecte de données non consentie. Mais plus important encore, le contrôle du levier d’accès à celles-ci par l’utilisateur lui-même. En d’autres mots, une pleine propriété des données. Les technologies numériques, quelles qu’elles soient dès le moment où il y a implication d’empreintes numériques personnelles, et les pratiques définies en matière de gestion de ces données par les propriétaires ou exploitant de ces technologies, doivent être pensées dans un cadre de souveraineté numérique individuelle pour chaque citoyen.

Souveraineté

Facebook, Google et consorts n’ont, en lumière du modèle économique de capitalisme de surveillance qui est le leur, et qui n’est rendu pérenne que grâce à une collecte massive de données personnelles, aucun intérêt à s’engager pour une plus grande souveraineté numérique de leurs utilisateurs. Ils peuvent promettre la vie privée sur leurs plateformes. Mais la vie privée sur Facebook ou Google ne veut pas dire pour autant la vie privée à l’égard de Facebook ou de Google. C’est cette distinction qui différencie un utilisateur véritablement souverain de ses données d’un utilisateur qui ne l’est pas et ne dispose que de contrôles à la marge.

En l’état, une telle souveraineté, qui écarterait l’idée de collecte en tant que captation automatique par le prestataire de services, n’existe pas à l’échelle du citoyen. Et parce que ces entreprises ne sont pas encouragées à agir, c’est au régulateur de se saisir de ces enjeux de façon cohérente. La sécurisation ou la protection des données dont le règlement européen sur la protection des données (GDPR) se fait le porte-drapeau, c’est la charrue avant les bœufs, car cela ne régule que la protection de données préalablement collectées, qu’elles soient conservées ou non. Ne pas réglementer le processus de collecte qui intervient en amont, c’est éluder la question principale qui permet le débat autour de la propriété des données. Et donc de la souveraineté numérique individuelle.

Approche collaborative

Si ledit règlement reste un bon pas en avant, porter l’enjeu de la souveraineté numérique individuelle n’est possible que grâce à une approche collaborative. Innovation et régulation continuent de fonctionner à deux vitesses. La politique des big tech consiste souvent à innover sans prise en considération particulière des enjeux qui en découlent ou pourraient en découler sur le plan juridique. Le régulateur, quant à lui, agit davantage dans un cadre réactif que proactif. Dès lors, si le régulateur est habitué à réguler les pratiques existantes, il l’est moins pour penser le champ du possible. Il faut éclater les silos ; les entreprises du numérique doivent travailler plus directement avec le régulateur pour penser innovation et régulation comme un tout, car celui-ci doit pouvoir réguler plus vite, et de manière appropriée. Proposer un éclatement de silos part du postulat que le numérique impacte de façon transversale toutes activités humaines.

Il y a dès lors nécessité à faire plus de “co” : coparticipation, coopération, collaboration. Les différentes parties prenantes, publiques et privées, doivent chercher davantage à se coordonner et à mettre l’accent sur le partage de leurs expertises respectives au travers d’interactions régulières qui leur permettent de s’adapter au contexte numérique rapidement changeant dans lequel ils opèrent. Une collaboration plus étroite entre innovateur et régulateur ne suffit pas pour penser la souveraineté numérique individuelle. À l’instar du contrat pour le Web impulsé par Tim Berners-Lee, il importe de responsabiliser les différentes parties prenantes, en ce compris les citoyens. La condition sine qua non à cette responsabilisation accrue passe par l’acquisition d’un bagage numérique suffisant et entretenu dans le temps. En matière d’éducation, par exemple, les citoyens doivent pouvoir bénéficier d’un effort public-privé au service d’un système d’apprentissage adapté aux réalités du XXIe siècle.

Considérer le citoyen comme responsable et partie prenante des enjeux de sa propre souveraineté numérique implique de permettre à chacun de bénéficier d’un système éducatif renouvelé. À cet égard, et à l’instar du quotient intellectuel ou émotionnel, il faut penser l’instauration d’une forme de quotient numérique à améliorer par des programmes de formation adaptés à l’acquisition de connaissances centrales à l’exercice de cette souveraineté.

Opinion

Facebook, Google et autres n’ont aucun intérêt à œuvrer pour plus de souveraineté numérique de leurs utilisateurs.

urn:contentItem:5Y1R-JV41-F03R-N3PS-00000-00A quantitative futurist explains how Amazon, Google, and Apple will 'completely dismantle' the healthcare industry — and says the wheels are already in motion2020-01-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:15:13ZLexisNexisA quantitative futurist explains how Amazon, Google, and Apple will 'completely dismantle' the healthcare industry — and says the wheels are already in motionJoe Ciolli

Jan 21, 2020( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Mike Jordan/Getty Images Amy Webb, a quantitative futurist and professor of strategic foresight at NYU, expects tech giants like Amazon and Apple to "completely dismantle the healthcare industry as we know it." "I would argue they're already in the process of doing that," Webb told Business Insider on the sidelines of the World Economic Forum Annual Meeting in Davos, Switzerland. Tech powerhouses like Google, Amazon, and Apple are increasingly focused on expanding in US healthcare through strategies that include opening health clinics, developing fitness trackers that can track health data, and building life-sciences teams. Click here for more BI Prime stories[1]. DAVOS, Switzerland — Tech companies are coming for the healthcare industry's lunch.

That's according to Amy Webb, a quantitative futurist and professor of strategic foresight at New York University Stern School of Business. When Business Insider asked Webb for a prediction she expects to happen that most others don't think will happen, her response turned to the relationship between big tech companies and healthcare. "Amazon, Google, and Apple completely dismantle the healthcare industry as we know it," Webb told Business Insider on the sidelines of the World Economic Forum Annual Meeting in Davos, Switzerland. "From diagnostics to pharmaceuticals to the physician-patient relationship, and I would argue they're already in the process of doing that," Webb said. Read more: Tech giants like Google and Amazon are beefing up their healthcare strategies. Here's how 7 tech titans are tackling the $3.6 trillion industry.[2] Tech powerhouses like Google, Amazon, and Apple are increasingly focused on expanding in US healthcare. They've pursued strategies such as building out life-sciences divisions[3] and offering hardware like fitness trackers, and even shown some signs that they'll get into the business of providing healthcare[4]. Tech companies have an advantage that established healthcare players don't when working to change how the healthcare industry operates. "Part of what is on their side is the regulatory issues that traditional players have to deal with don't apply in the same way," Webb said, referring to the regulations that protect patient-data privacy within doctors' offices and other established healthcare institutions[5]. "We could, 20 years from now, have a completely different approach with completely different providers." Read more: Verily just presented for the first time at JPMorgan's big health conference. Here's how the CEO of Alphabet's life sciences firm laid out the unusual business to top investors.[6] Webb pointed in particular to the tools getting developed that collect information about our health, such as wearables like Fitbit, which Google is acquiring[7], and the Apple Watch[8] and voice assistants like Amazon's Alexa.[9] In the future, that information and other sensors and tools could be used to get a better picture of a patient's health without a doctor's office visit. That goes beyond the initial intention of the devices. "What's happening in a sort of transparent way — because this is not the primary use case for all these technologies — is our homes are being turned into clinics," Webb said.NOW WATCH: A big-money investor in juggernauts like Facebook and Netflix breaks down the '3rd wave' firms that are leading the next round of tech disruption[10]See Also: Investor Joel Greenblatt is crushing 96% of peers by adding a unique twist to the famed strategies of Warren Buffett and Ben Graham. He shared with us his winning approach.[11]A Wall Street firm names 9 stocks that look like big winners as earnings get underway — and 9 more that could be headed for a plunge[12]Private-equity giant KKR warns WeWork's fiasco is just the start of many more funding struggles for unicorns— and spells out 4 areas where it's investing instead[13] [ 1]: urn:contentItem:5PT5-FT11-JBG3-6055-00000-00Aramco Chief Says I.P.O. Is on Track for 2018: DealBook Briefing2017-10-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:15:12ZLexisNexisBUSINESSdealbookAramco Chief Says I.P.O. Is on Track for 2018: DealBook BriefingANDREW ROSS SORKIN, MICHAEL J. de la MERCED and AMIE TSANG

The oil giant’s chief executive denied that the company’s forthcoming stock sale faced delays, but gave few details of what the offering would look like.

Good Monday morning from Andrew Ross Sorkin in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, and Michael J. de la Merced and Amie Tsang in London. Andrew spent Sunday in Dhahran taping a television interview for CNBC at Saudi Aramco’s headquarters with its C.E.O. ahead of the kingdom’s Future of Finance Initiative — known informally as Davos in the Desert — that starts Tuesday morning.

Throughout the week, we’ll bring you all the back-room chatter and details about an Aramco I.P.O.

A reminder: DealBook’s sixth annual conference, Playing for the Long Term, is on Nov. 9. Want to join us? Apply to participate here.

Aramco Says It’s on Track for a 2018 I.P.O.

But the question the Saudi oil giant has been careful to avoid answering is: Where will that offering take place?

Amin Nasser, the oil giant’s chief executive, told Andrew that the listing remained on track and denied reports that it could be delayed or shelved in favor of selling private shares.

Here’s an excerpt from the Nasser interview:

“We have always said that we will be listing in 2018, and to be more specific, in the second half of 2018. However, I think journalists and writers — they are expecting more and more information, and we are governed by, you know, certain rules with regard to talking about the I.P.O. and all of that.”

Note that Mr. Nasser doesn’t mention whether both parts of a potential Aramco I.P.O. — listings on both Saudi Arabia’s Tadawul exchange and on an international stock market like the N.Y.S.E. or the London Stock Exchange — are on track. He also denied that the company was talking with Chinese investors about a private placement. But do remember to parse those remarks: It is possible that the kingdom, not the company, would negotiate with the Chinese or others.

The bottom line: Potential public market investors shouldn’t worry about Aramco’s historically opaque management structure. “I can say Aramco has always been run like a publicly traded company,” Mr. Nasser said.

What About Kevin Warsh?

He wasn’t among the three people whom President Trump mentioned by name in an interview with Fox Business Network as a leading candidate for Federal Reserve chairman.

For the betting types, here’s what Mr. Trump told Maria Bartiromo: “I’ve been seeing a number of people and most people are saying it’s down to two, Mr. Taylor, Mr. Powell. I also met with Janet Yellen, who I like a lot.”

That may mean that John B. Taylor of Stanford University, who reportedly has the backing of Mike Pence, is the interest rate hawk more likely than Mr. Warsh to be nominated.

The current rumor making its way around Washington is that Jerome Powell will be named Fed chairman and represent continuity with Ms. Yellen’s policies, while Mr. Taylor will be vice chairman.

But as an unidentified White House official said of Mr. Trump to Jonathan Swan of Axios: “It’s never a done deal with this guy.”

Let’s Talk About That Fourth Tax Bracket

For a plan that White House officials publicly hope can be passed by year’s end, the proposed Republican tax overhaul still seems awfully in flux. The latest idea: creating what’s essentially a fourth tax bracket by giving those who earn at least $1 million a year a top marginal rate of 39.6 percent.

Mr. Trump is on board with what he called a “fifth” tax bracket, for now. “If I feel that the middle class is not getting what I want them to get, and that’s going to be a lot, because I want them to get really a lot. Then I’m going to do a fifth bracket, which will give them more,” he told Fox News.

But Grover Norquist of Americans for Tax Reform is livid, telling Axios: “This isn’t the dumbest idea I have ever heard of. But it is in the top 20.”

Don’t forget about corporate taxes

Top economists from the Obama administration took hard swings at arguments by the current Council of Economic Advisers in favor of reducing taxes for corporate America. Larry Summers wrote in The Washington Post this weekend: “The primary impact of a corporate tax cut would be to raise after-tax profits and the stock market. This in turn, as I noted, primarily benefits wealthy individuals.” (WaPo)

And Jason Furman, a former head of the C.E.A., wrote in a Wall Street Journal op-ed: “A well-designed business-tax reform has the potential to raise productivity and wages. But this proposal is not well-designed, and flawed analysis only makes achieving well-designed reform less likely.” (WSJ)

On the agenda this week

Ivanka Trump is headed to a town-hall meeting in Pennsylvania today to talk tax reform, and in particular to argue for expanding the child tax credit.

Mr. Trump is scheduled to attend Senate Republicans’ weekly policy lunch tomorrow to discuss taxes.

A Veteran Venture Capitalist Joins Eduardo Saverin

Howard L. Morgan was an early executive at Renaissance Technologies and co-founded the successful venture firm First Round Capital. Now he’s joining B Capital, the investment firm co-led by Eduardo Saverin of Facebook fame, reports Michael de la Merced.

“Howard, at the end of the day, is a giant in the industry,” Mr. Saverin told Michael in an interview. “You can gain a tremendous amount of perspective just from speaking with him for a couple of minutes.”

What Mr. Morgan will do: Help B Capital develop a culture — as he did at First Round — and offer guidance as the firm looks for new investment opportunities, particularly in Asia.

New Troubles for Fox in Wake of O’Reilly Revelations?

Remember what Fox is already dealing with: It’s seeking approval from the British government for its takeover of the broadcaster Sky, and the Justice Department is still investigating Fox News’s settlements with women who accused Roger Ailes of sexual harassment.

So the huge report by Emily Steel and Mike Schmidt of the NYT on a $32 million settlement between Bill O’Reilly and a longtime network analyst has turned up the heat on Rupert Murdoch and his sons.

What did the Murdochs know? From the NYT:

Asked about the allegation of a nonconsensual sexual relationship, a representative for Mr. O’Reilly, Mark Fabiani, said that 21st Century Fox was “well aware” Ms. Wiehl had signed a sworn affidavit “renouncing all allegations against him,” adding that after receiving the document Fox News offered Mr. O’Reilly “a record-breaking contract.”

Mr. O’Reilly tweeted that he will respond more fully today:

And then there was Fidelity

Two longtime employees at the mutual fund giant, Gavin Baker and Robert Chow, were fired or resigned this month after accusations of sexual harassment, according to Sarah Krouse and Kirsten Grind of the WSJ.

Brian Hogan, president of Fidelity’s stock-picking division, held an emergency meeting to stress the firm’s “zero tolerance policy.” From the WSJ:

The issue of workplace conduct has been simmering within Fidelity’s stock-picking unit in particular for years. A 2015 internal report warned of cultural problems particularly adverse for women, according to interviews with more than a dozen former Fidelity analysts and portfolio managers.

More must-reads

Susan Fowler sat down with Maureen Dowd for her first interview since blowing the whistle on harassment at Uber: “I knew I had to be super-careful about how I said it if I wanted anybody to take it seriously.” (NYT)

Amazon is doing some soul-searching after Roy Price, now the former leader of Amazon Studios, was accused of harassment. (NYT)

Jim Rutenberg of the NYT looks at the widespread use of nondisclosure agreements that helped hide many of these sexual harassment accusations. (NYT)

Abenomics Will Continue

The Nikkei 225 closed up 1.11 percent — to its highest point since 1996 — in the wake of Shinzo Abe’s commanding victory.

Motoko Rich of the NYT writes, “With the economy slowly improving, voters also seemed willing to accept Mr. Abe’s plan to raise a consumption tax that he has vowed to apply to child care and free university and college tuition.”

Peter Tasker of Arcus Research writes in the Nikkei Asian Review that it isn’t clear whether the Bank of Japan governor, Haruhiko Kuroda, will stay on for another five-year term. But it’s likely that any successor would maintain the current fiscal policy.

In other global monetary news

The euro has quavered as investors watch for a response from Catalan separatists to Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy’s move to stamp his authority on the region. (Bloomberg)

In Argentina, President Mauricio Macri gained ground in congressional midterm elections. Improved prospects for his Cambiemos alliance have helped pull up the peso and Argentine bonds. (Bloomberg)

The Speed Read

M.&A.

The online lenderSoFi explored selling itself earlier this year for as much as $10 billion, but couldn’t find any takers at that price, according to people familiar with the matter. (FT)

Carlyle has joined the takeover battle for the fund business at Old Mutual Global Investors, joining two Australian financial services groups and TA Associates, according to people close to the process. (FT)

Cisco is close to buying Broadsoft, a software maker with a market value of about $1.7 billion, according to people with knowledge of the situation. (Bloomberg)

Anbang Insurance Group has resumed sales of the high-yield investment products that financed its global acquisition spree, suggesting that regulators intend to throw a lifeline to the group. (FT)

Potlatch is near to an all-stock deal to combine with Deltic Timber, according to people familiar with the matter. (WSJ)

Policy and Legal

The European Central Bank is expected to begin unwinding its monetary stimulus program and a tighter policy could bolster the value of the euro and the currencies that track it. (WSJ)

Banks and Banking

The next generation of Wall Street titans thinks that learning Python is more important than learning Mandarin. (Quartz)

Morgan Stanley’s Ted Pick, who is considered a potential successor to James Gorman as C.E.O., has been credited with helping the bank to beat Goldman Sachs in revenue from trades. (FT)

I.P.O.s and Offerings

Qatar’s sovereign wealth fund is in talks about taking a stake in the Russian power group, EN+, which is seeking to raise $1.5 billion in an initial public offering. (FT)

Business and Economy

Tesla could be the first foreign automaker to build a wholly owned manufacturing operation in China. (NYT)

In related news, China’s state chemical group is among the bidders for a $4 billion stake in SQM, one of the world’s largest producers of lithium, a key component in the batteries of electric cars. (FT)

Jordan Belfort has dismissed the craze for initial coin offerings as “the biggest scam ever” and one that is bound to “blow up” in people’s faces. (FT)

Nearly all big tech companies have an artificial intelligence project, and they are willing to pay experts millions of dollars to help get the job done. (NYT)

Huge warehouses are being built, fueling a demand for lower-skilled workers and reviving areas that once relied on manufacturing. (NYT)

Follow Andrew Ross Sorkin @andrewrsorkin, Michael J. de la Merced @m_delamercedand Amie Tsang @amietsang on Twitter.

urn:contentItem:5PSW-K1X1-DXY4-X195-00000-00Aramco Chief Says I.P.O. Is on Track for 2018: DealBook Briefing2017-10-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:15:12ZLexisNexisSection Column 0Business/Financial DeskPg. Aramco Chief Says I.P.O. Is on Track for 2018: DealBook BriefingBy ANDREW ROSS SORKIN, MICHAEL J. de la MERCED and AMIE TSANG

Follow Andrew Ross Sorkin @andrewrsorkin, Michael J. de la Merced @m_delamercedand Amie Tsang @amietsang on Twitter.

Good Monday morning from Andrew Ross Sorkin in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, and Michael J. de la Merced and Amie Tsang in London. Andrew spent Sunday in Dhahran taping a television interview for CNBC at Saudi Aramco's headquarters with its C.E.O. ahead of the kingdom's Future of Finance Initiative -- known informally as Davos in the Desert -- that starts Tuesday morning.

Throughout the week, we'll bring you all the back-room chatter and details about an Aramco I.P.O.

A reminder: DealBook's sixth annual conference, Playing for the Long Term, is on Nov. 9. Want to join us? Apply to participate here.

Aramco Says It's on Track for a 2018 I.P.O.

But the question the Saudi oil giant has been careful to avoid answering is: Where will that offering take place?

Amin Nasser, the oil giant's chief executive, told Andrew that the listing remained on track and denied reports that it could be delayed or shelved in favor of selling private shares.

Here's an excerpt from the Nasser interview:

''We have always said that we will be listing in 2018, and to be more specific, in the second half of 2018. However, I think journalists and writers -- they are expecting more and more information, and we are governed by, you know, certain rules with regard to talking about the I.P.O. and all of that.''

Note that Mr. Nasser doesn't mention whether both parts of a potential Aramco I.P.O. -- listings on both Saudi Arabia's Tadawul exchange and on an international stock market like the N.Y.S.E. or the London Stock Exchange -- are on track. He also denied that the company was talking with Chinese investors about a private placement. But do remember to parse those remarks: It is possible that the kingdom, not the company, would negotiate with the Chinese or others.

The bottom line: Potential public market investors shouldn't worry about Aramco's historically opaque management structure. ''I can say Aramco has always been run like a publicly traded company,'' Mr. Nasser said.

What About Kevin Warsh?

He wasn't among the three people whom President Trump mentioned by name in an interview with Fox Business Network as a leading candidate for Federal Reserve chairman.

For the betting types, here's what Mr. Trump told Maria Bartiromo: ''I've been seeing a number of people and most people are saying it's down to two, Mr. Taylor, Mr. Powell. I also met with Janet Yellen, who I like a lot.''

That may mean that John B. Taylor of Stanford University, who reportedly has the backing of Mike Pence, is the interest rate hawk more likely than Mr. Warsh to be nominated.

The current rumor making its way around Washington is that Jerome Powell will be named Fed chairman and represent continuity with Ms. Yellen's policies, while Mr. Taylor will be vice chairman.

But as an unidentified White House official said of Mr. Trump to Jonathan Swan of Axios: ''It's never a done deal with this guy.''

Let's Talk About That Fourth Tax Bracket

For a plan that White House officials publicly hope can be passed by year's end, the proposed Republican tax overhaul still seems awfully in flux. The latest idea: creating what's essentially a fourth tax bracket by giving those who earn at least $1 million a year a top marginal rate of 39.6 percent.

Mr. Trump is on board with what he called a ''fifth'' tax bracket, for now. ''If I feel that the middle class is not getting what I want them to get, and that's going to be a lot, because I want them to get really a lot. Then I'm going to do a fifth bracket, which will give them more,'' he told Fox News.

But Grover Norquist of Americans for Tax Reform is livid, telling Axios: ''This isn't the dumbest idea I have ever heard of. But it is in the top 20.''

Don't forget about corporate taxes

Top economists from the Obama administration took hard swings at arguments by the current Council of Economic Advisers in favor of reducing taxes for corporate America. Larry Summers wrote in The Washington Post this weekend: ''The primary impact of a corporate tax cut would be to raise after-tax profits and the stock market. This in turn, as I noted, primarily benefits wealthy individuals.'' (WaPo)

And Jason Furman, a former head of the C.E.A., wrote in a Wall Street Journal op-ed: ''A well-designed business-tax reform has the potential to raise productivity and wages. But this proposal is not well-designed, and flawed analysis only makes achieving well-designed reform less likely.'' (WSJ)

On the agenda this week

Ivanka Trump is headed to a town-hall meeting in Pennsylvania today to talk tax reform, and in particular to argue for expanding the child tax credit.

Mr. Trump is scheduled to attend Senate Republicans' weekly policy lunch tomorrow to discuss taxes.

A Veteran Venture Capitalist Joins Eduardo Saverin

Howard L. Morgan was an early executive at Renaissance Technologies and co-founded the successful venture firm First Round Capital. Now he's joining B Capital, the investment firm co-led by Eduardo Saverin of Facebook fame, reports Michael de la Merced.

''Howard, at the end of the day, is a giant in the industry,'' Mr. Saverin told Michael in an interview. ''You can gain a tremendous amount of perspective just from speaking with him for a couple of minutes.''

What Mr. Morgan will do: Help B Capital develop a culture -- as he did at First Round -- and offer guidance as the firm looks for new investment opportunities, particularly in Asia.

New Troubles for Fox in Wake of O'Reilly Revelations?

Remember what Fox is already dealing with: It's seeking approval from the British government for its takeover of the broadcaster Sky, and the Justice Department is still investigating Fox News's settlements with women who accused Roger Ailes of sexual harassment.

So the huge report by Emily Steel and Mike Schmidt of the NYT on a $32 million settlement between Bill O'Reilly and a longtime network analyst has turned up the heat on Rupert Murdoch and his sons.

What did the Murdochs know? From the NYT:

Asked about the allegation of a nonconsensual sexual relationship, a representative for Mr. O'Reilly, Mark Fabiani, said that 21st Century Fox was ''well aware'' Ms. Wiehl had signed a sworn affidavit ''renouncing all allegations against him,'' adding that after receiving the document Fox News offered Mr. O'Reilly ''a record-breaking contract.''

Mr. O'Reilly tweeted that he will respond more fully today:

And then there was Fidelity

Two longtime employees at the mutual fund giant, Gavin Baker and Robert Chow, were fired or resigned this month after accusations of sexual harassment, according to Sarah Krouse and Kirsten Grind of the WSJ.

Brian Hogan, president of Fidelity's stock-picking division, held an emergency meeting to stress the firm's ''zero tolerance policy.'' From the WSJ:

The issue of workplace conduct has been simmering within Fidelity's stock-picking unit in particular for years. A 2015 internal report warned of cultural problems particularly adverse for women, according to interviews with more than a dozen former Fidelity analysts and portfolio managers.

More must-reads

Susan Fowler sat down with Maureen Dowd for her first interview since blowing the whistle on harassment at Uber: ''I knew I had to be super-careful about how I said it if I wanted anybody to take it seriously.'' (NYT)

Amazon is doing some soul-searching after Roy Price, now the former leader of Amazon Studios, was accused of harassment. (NYT)

Jim Rutenberg of the NYT looks at the widespread use of nondisclosure agreements that helped hide many of these sexual harassment accusations. (NYT)

Abenomics Will Continue

The Nikkei 225 closed up 1.11 percent -- to its highest point since 1996 -- in the wake of Shinzo Abe's commanding victory.

Motoko Rich of the NYT writes, ''With the economy slowly improving, voters also seemed willing to accept Mr. Abe's plan to raise a consumption tax that he has vowed to apply to child care and free university and college tuition.''

Peter Tasker of Arcus Research writes in the Nikkei Asian Review that it isn't clear whether the Bank of Japan governor, Haruhiko Kuroda, will stay on for another five-year term. But it's likely that any successor would maintain the current fiscal policy.

In other global monetary news

The euro has quavered as investors watch for a response from Catalan separatists to Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy's move to stamp his authority on the region. (Bloomberg)

In Argentina, President Mauricio Macri gained ground in congressional midterm elections. Improved prospects for his Cambiemos alliance have helped pull up the peso and Argentine bonds. (Bloomberg)

The Speed Read

M.&A.

The online lender SoFi explored selling itself earlier this year for as much as $10 billion, but couldn't find any takers at that price, according to people familiar with the matter. (FT)

Carlyle has joined the takeover battle for the fund business at Old Mutual Global Investors, joining two Australian financial services groups and TA Associates, according to people close to the process. (FT)

Cisco is close to buying Broadsoft, a software maker with a market value of about $1.7 billion, according to people with knowledge of the situation. (Bloomberg)

Anbang Insurance Group has resumed sales of the high-yield investment products that financed its global acquisition spree, suggesting that regulators intend to throw a lifeline to the group. (FT)

Potlatch is near to an all-stock deal to combine with Deltic Timber, according to people familiar with the matter. (WSJ)

Policy and Legal

The European Central Bank is expected to begin unwinding its monetary stimulus program and a tighter policy could bolster the value of the euro and the currencies that track it. (WSJ)

Banks and Banking

The next generation of Wall Street titans thinks that learning Python is more important than learning Mandarin. (Quartz)

Morgan Stanley's Ted Pick, who is considered a potential successor to James Gorman as C.E.O., has been credited with helping the bank to beat Goldman Sachs in revenue from trades. (FT)

I.P.O.s and Offerings

Qatar's sovereign wealth fund is in talks about taking a stake in the Russian power group, EN+, which is seeking to raise $1.5 billion in an initial public offering. (FT)

Business and Economy

Tesla could be the first foreign automaker to build a wholly owned manufacturing operation in China. (NYT)

In related news, China's state chemical group is among the bidders for a $4 billion stake in SQM, one of the world's largest producers of lithium, a key component in the batteries of electric cars. (FT)

Jordan Belfort has dismissed the craze for initial coin offerings as ''the biggest scam ever'' and one that is bound to ''blow up'' in people's faces. (FT)

Nearly all big tech companies have an artificial intelligence project, and they are willing to pay experts millions of dollars to help get the job done. (NYT)

Huge warehouses are being built, fueling a demand for lower-skilled workers and reviving areas that once relied on manufacturing. (NYT)

urn:contentItem:5WN0-2031-DXH2-645N-00000-00A Rare Pair Of 1972 Nike Running Shoes Just Sold For An Out Of This World Price Tag, CBS2019-07-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:15:13ZLexisNexisCBS MORNING NEWS4:00 AM ESTNEWS072403cb.400A Rare Pair Of 1972 Nike Running Shoes Just Sold For An Out Of This World Price Tag, CBSAnne-Marie Green, Wendy Gillette

Forever 21 is facing backlash for sending diet bars with clothing deliveries

ANNE-MARIE GREEN: A rare pair of 1972 Nike running shoes just sold for an out-of-this-world price tag. The so-called Nike Moon Shoe sold for four hundred and thirty-seven thousand five hundred dollars yesterday. The sale set a new world record for sneakers sold at public auction. The pair of shoes were one of only twelve made by Nike for the 1972 Olympic trials. The buyer was a Canadian businessman. The previous record was for a pair of signed Michael Jordan Converse worn during the 1984 gold medal-winning Olympic final.

On the CBS MoneyWatch now, retailer Forever 21 is facing backlash for sending diet bars with clothing deliveries, and UPS is making big changes so you can get your packages faster. Wendy Gillette is at the New York Stock Exchange with that and more. Good morning, Wendy.

WENDY GILLETTE: Good morning, Anne-Marie. Earning season is in full swing. And notable companies reporting today include embattled industrial giant Boeing, Facebook, Tesla, machinery maker Caterpillar and UPS. Stocks rose again Tuesday with growth from banks and technology companies. The Dow was up one hundred and seventy-seven points. The S&P 500 gained twenty. And the NASDAQ added forty-seven.

The Justice Department is opening a massive anti-trust investigation into big tech companies. The agency wants to know whether their online platforms hurt competition, suppressed innovation, or harmed consumers. The investigation comes as a growing number of lawmakers are calling for stricter regulations or even breaking up big tech companies. Several tech giants are under intense scrutiny following scandals that compromise users` privacy.

UPS is making big changes so customers can get deliveries faster. The company is adding twelve thousand new spots where people can pick up their packages. They`re inside CVS, Michael`s, and Advance Auto Part stores. The company will also offer pickup and delivery services seven days a week starting next year. UPS is also expanding its drone delivery operations. Right now, they are limited to bringing medical samples to hospitals in North Carolina.

Ford claims its new all-electric F-150 just did what no truck has ever done before. The company released video of it pulling ten double-decker freight cars weighing more than one million pounds. Ford has not said how much the truck will cost. The company called the stunt a one-time demonstration and said the prototype is towing far beyond any production truck`s capacity.

And Forever 21 is apologizing for a marketing campaign, including diet bars with customers` online orders. The promotion came to the attention of social media users after customers who bought plus-size clothing noticed an Atkins bar was included with their order. Some felt it sent a message they should lose weight. It was later revealed the diet bar samples were included in all online orders regardless of the size. The samples have since been removed from orders. The power of social media. Anne-Marie.

ANNE-MARIE GREEN: That is so true. And, you know, their target--the customers or young women, you know, no matter what size. They-- they always have to sort of be aware of the messaging that they are sending out. Because you`re right--

WENDY GILLETTE: Mm-Hm.

ANNE-MARIE GREEN: --everyone goes online and uploads those pictures.

WENDY GILLETTE: Yeah.

ANNE-MARIE GREEN: Wendy Gillette at the New York Stock Exchange. Thank you, Wendy.

Still to come, criminals get creative. Why more than a dozen snow globes receives by police in Australia prompting an international investigation.

(ANNOUNCEMENTS)

ANNE-MARIE GREEN: I don`t think so. A Colorado homeowner got an unwelcome visit from a snake. After opening the Ring app to see who is at the door, the homeowner was shocked to see a large snake. The uninvited guest slithered around the doorbell and across the camera frame.

Criminals got very creative when trying to smuggle illegal drugs into Australia. Police announced yesterday, they seized fifteen snow globes containing liquid meth worth one million dollars. The snow globes were X- rayed after the contraband arrived from Canada. They tested positive for the addictive and dangerous substance.

And a four-year-old boy is getting worldwide attention for his drumming skills on a homemade drum set.

(Hosea Moneda performing; internet video)

ANNE-MARIE GREEN: Hosea Moneda, who lives in the Philippines, was played-- has played the drums, rather, since he was two years old. His dad made him this drum set with cans, lids, tape and other everyday items. Hosea`s mother took the adorable video and then put it on social media where it quickly spread across the globe.

Coming up on CBS THIS MORNING, we`re going to bring you former Special Counsel Robert Mueller`s highly-anticipated testimony. Our special coverage begins at eight fifteen.

(ANNOUNCEMENTS)

urn:contentItem:5WG3-PJK1-JBCN-42W9-00000-00ARBOR OUTLOOK: Big Tech, breakups and The Kinks2019-06-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:15:12ZLexisNexisNEWSARBOR OUTLOOK: Big Tech, breakups and The KinksMargaret McDowell | Arbor Outlook

"Corporations, big business and egos ... When it all gets too bad." from "The Road" as performed by The Kinks

The calls for regulation of America's largest technology companies are growing daily. The Big Tech backlash also appears to be one of the few topics that transcends political parties and ideologies.

Some say we need to copy and impose our own version of the European Union's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which qualifies as the first major data and privacy law of its kind anywhere on the globe. Others say we simply need to break up these giants because they are stifling competition and abusing their power.

The history of antitrust regulation in America is complicated, complex and nuanced. During the attempts to break up Rockefeller's Standard Oil, the structure of the entire country's energy supply was at stake. And apart from Rockefeller's employees, heirs and philanthropic recipients, the country was largely supportive of splintering that mega-corporate monopoly.

Today's tech giants don't control the nation's natural resources or railroads; they also don't control the supply of food, water, medicine or housing. Instead, the modern "monopolies" largely control information and our access to it. They know where we are, what we're doing, where we're going to be and when, what we're likely to buy, and even what we're thinking.

This may sound Orwellian, but the reality is that we all willingly and for the most part knowingly opt in to these services simply to make our lives easier. Orwell's dystopian future may yet come, but for now we look more like characters in Aldous Huxley's "Brave New World," where citizens gladly accept the convenient status quo at the expense of freedom and privacy.

Most of these services are free and dramatically improve the quality of our lives. That should certainly count for something. Remember the days when you would ask yourself a question and had to live with not knowing until someone told you or you read it somewhere? Now, thanks to Big Tech, we have an infinite supply of information at our fingertips, or more specifically, ready to respond to our voice queries.

From an investment perspective, the history of antitrust legislation tells us investors shouldn't fear full-blown breakups of Big Tech. It's been a long time since the United States broke up a large corporation for antitrust reasons. It's a long and difficult process. Secondly, the current iterations of all the major companies that have been broken up or had punitive antitrust rulings against them in the modern era are worth far more today than at the time of the antitrust actions. It's possible that breaking up Big Tech creates more shareholder wealth than it destroys.

But who knows? Just ask Siri.

Margaret R. McDowell, ChFC, AIF, author of the syndicated economic column "Arbor Outlook," is the founder of Arbor Wealth Management, LLC, (850-608-6121 www.arborwealth.net), a "fee-only" registered investment advisory firm located near Sandestin.
